title: Judgment on Jerusalem
shortSummary: Ezekiel 22 presents a solemn indictment of Jerusalem for its rampant sin, including bloodshed, idolatry, and social injustice. The chapter reveals God's righteous judgment upon the city and its leaders, emphasizing the consequences of persistent rebellion and the absence of a faithful intercessor.
timeline: c. 593 BC - Early Babylonian Exile period, during Ezekiel's prophetic ministry

keyCharacters.name: Ezekiel
keyCharacters.description: The prophet called by God to deliver messages of judgment and hope to Israel, serving as God's spokesman in this chapter.

keyCharacters.name: Princes of Israel
keyCharacters.description: The political leaders of Jerusalem who are condemned for their bloodshed and oppression.

keyCharacters.name: Prophets of Israel
keyCharacters.description: False prophets accused of conspiracy, greed, and misleading the people with lies.

keyCharacters.name: Priests of Israel
keyCharacters.description: Religious leaders who profaned God's law and holy things, failing to distinguish between holy and profane.

definitions.definition: A title used by God to address Ezekiel, emphasizing his humanity and role as a representative of the people.
Impurities separated from precious metals during refining, symbolizing moral and spiritual corruption.
Holy days commanded by God for rest and worship, which were profaned by the people and leaders.
A metaphor describing false prophets who build their messages on unstable, deceitful foundations.

outline.heading: God’s Charge Against Jerusalem’s Sin
outline.description: God commands Ezekiel to judge Jerusalem, exposing its bloodshed and idolatry that defile the city and bring reproach among nations.

outline.heading: Specific Sins of Leaders and People
outline.description: The princes, people, and society are condemned for shedding blood, oppression, idolatry, and various sexual sins, highlighting the depth of moral decay.

outline.heading: The Refining Judgment of God
outline.description: God compares Israel to dross in a furnace, declaring His intent to gather and refine them through judgment to reveal His holiness and justice.

outline.heading: Corruption Among Prophets, Priests, and Princes
outline.description: The leaders and religious officials are accused of conspiracy, greed, profaning God’s law, and misleading the people, worsening the nation’s guilt.

outline.heading: God’s Search for a Faithful Intercessor
outline.description: God laments the absence of anyone to stand in the gap in prayer and intercession, resulting in His pouring out wrath upon the people.

application: Examine your own life for hidden sins and repent to avoid the judgment that comes from persistent rebellion against God.
Pray earnestly for your community and leaders, standing in the gap as intercessors to seek God's mercy and restoration.
Honor God's holy days and commandments faithfully, understanding that profaning them leads to spiritual decay.
Beware of false teaching and remain grounded in Scripture to discern truth from deception.

keyVerses.text: And I sought for a man among them, that should make up the hedge, and stand in the gap before me for the land, that I should not destroy it: but I found none.
keyVerses.significance: This verse highlights the desperate need for faithful intercessors to pray and stand for their people before God’s judgment.

keyVerses.text: Son of man, the house of Israel is to me become dross: all they are brass, and tin, and iron, and lead, in the midst of the furnace; they are even the dross of silver.
keyVerses.significance: It illustrates Israel’s moral impurity and the necessity of God’s refining judgment to purify His people.

keyVerses.text: Therefore have I poured out mine indignation upon them; I have consumed them with the fire of my wrath: their own way have I recompensed upon their heads, saith the Lord GOD.
keyVerses.significance: This verse underscores the certainty of divine judgment as a just recompense for persistent sin.
